commentary.line: So, that's all we have from this game. Many thanks for your company. Do join us tomorrow for the battle between two Asian nations, Afghanistan and Bangladesh. On behalf of Akshay, Pradeep, Sonali, Sriram, Krishna and Bhanu, this is Sidhant signing off. See you tomorrow folks. Take care.

Let's take a look at some of the interesting tweets about this game:

Mohandas Menon: New Zealand won by 3 wkts with 151 balls to spare: this is the narrowest win with most balls to spare in ODI cricket history #NZvSco #CWC15

Mazher Arshad: New Zealand's last 10 completed ODIs: W W W W L W W W L W

Iain O'Brien: Saying that @CricketScotland have "fought admirably" is doing them a disservice. Theyâ€™ve just gone out there and played cricket.

Jamie Alter: A win for NZ, but plenty of concerns with the batting. Well bowled, Scotland. If only the fielding and batting were better #NZvSCO #CWC15

Roshan Abeysinghe: NZ may not lose to the Scots but they are definitely wobbling. Great start to the tournament for the 2 associates.

Brendon McCullum: "It was a tough one. Credit to Scotland in the way they hung in there, especially after being four for 12. Lesser teams would have been rolled over there. Credit to them for the way they hung in and managed to post a total which was going to be tricky on that sort of a surface. It was just nibbling enough. And they had the bowlers who could extract a little bit out of it. Pleased with the result at the end. Probably a little bit nervous towards the end. With 25 overs to go, we will take the result and the points from this game. They are world class bowlers (Boult and Southee). They have stood up in red ball cricket for a long time. And as a pair we have seen how effective they can be, with one swinging it away from the right-hander and the other swinging it away from the left-hander. So, they were outstanding. When you win the toss and bowl, you hope to take early wickets. And getting them to 4 for 12 was an outstanding achievement. And also with the way we finished off the innings and after a partnership with a couple of their guys. It was a really good performance in the field and with the ball and with the bat we showed glimpses. I guess, we need to improve on that. Obviously a different situation, different surface, different ground. It is a day/night game as well (talking about the next game). It is going to be a great challenge and it is nice to have started the competition with two wins. But there is a long way to go in this competition, we know that. And we are just going to keep making small improvements on the way but we are playing some good cricket. England we know, are probably hurting a little bit at the moment. They will turn up and they will be tough to beat over here. So we have to play incredibly well and I believe it's a full house at Wellington. So it should be a great atmosphere. This is certainly the strongest side I have played in (replying to a twitter question asking whether it was the strongest team that McCullum has played in)."

Preston Mommsen: "It was a very tough start for us. The ball was doing a little bit more than expected. And to be fair they bowled really well and exploited the conditions. Unfortunately, we lost a few early ones but credit to the way Matthew (Machan) and Richie (Berrington) batted in the middle. I think they showed what we are capable of. Unfortunately they couldn't go on and we were well below par in the target we set. I think when we put the ball in the right areas, we got the rewards. Joshy (Josh Davey) and Wardy (Iain Wardlaw) bowled well for us. Unfortunately we couldn't pick those extra three but I am very proud of the fight in the end there. Great character. We are not shy of the fact that we are a very inexperienced team performing at the World Cup. So, it is good to get the first game out of the way. I am very proud of the performance and now ready for England."

Trent Boult: "I felt pretty good. I thought the ball swung around pretty nicely and I guess wicket had a bit of assistance in it as well. Pretty good bowling performance and everyone had a bit of a bat as well. And we got the job done. I actually slept alright. We got there in the end anyway. And I had a big role to play today. Like I said, everyone played well and we got the job done. The ball did swing for a little bit longer. Like I said the pace was there as well. We didn't really expect that. We just came in and tried to do what we have been doing for the last couple of weeks. And things fell into place and we got the result. It's going well and I am really enjoying the white ball form. A lot more opportunities coming up and need to make most of those."
Trent Boult is the Man of the Match for his figures of 2/21 in 6 overs.

The Black Caps batters looked like they were in a hurry to chase the total down and kept playing their shots even after a wicket had fallen. One can never know if things would have been any different had Scotland not dropped a couple of catches as well. As it turns out, the Kiwis managed to scrape through to a 3-wicket win, but it was not a convincing one. Davey and Wardlaw both finished with 3 wickets for Scotland.

Earlier, Scotland got off to a disastrous start, losing 4 wickets in under 5 overs. 3 out of those 4 wickets were ducks. However, Machan and Berrington showed resolve and batted sensibly after that. Machan got to his fifty and perished soon after, caught at mid-on, with Brendon McCullum taking a superb catch to end his 97-run stand with Berrington. After Machan got out, the floodgates opened. Anderson picked up his second wicket, dismissing the well-set Berrington on 50. From there on, it was all Vettori, who took the final three wickets to end the Scottish innings on 142. Two of those Vettori wickets came off consecutive balls. Overall, it was the third occasion in the innings, when a bowler had picked 2 wickets in 2 balls. First Boult did it, then Southee and finally, Vettori. Five Scottish batsmen got out on ducks and out of those, 4 were golden ducks.

New Zealand started the run-chase in superb fashion, with Guptill going hard at the new ball. However, he got out after hitting 4 boundaries and then Brendon McCullum took over the aggressor's role, smashing three boundaries, before he departed as well. The Kiwis were 48/2 at that stage when Taylor joined Williamson at the crease. Both of them then batted sensibly for two overs, before lunch was taken. After lunch, New Zealand came out looking to finish the job quickly, but Taylor soon fell trying to slog one out of the park. Elliott and Williamson then put on a good 40-run partnership but Williamson, who was looking in great touch, got out to Davey in the 18th over. Elliott also departed after making a good looking 29 to leave the Kiwis stuttering at 117/5. Anderson was dropped by Wardlaw on 5, but failed to cash in on the reprieve he got. Ronchi also got out soon, trying to play his shots, with the score reading 137/7 at that stage. But, Vettori and Milne made sure that they didn't lose any more wickets and took their team home.
The players shake hands with each other. The New Zealand dressing room looks relieved. The Scotland players walk back solemnly. They did well to ruffle the hosts, defending such a meagre total.

24.5   Iain Wardlaw to Vettori, FOUR, New Zealand win their second game in the tournament! They had to fight hard for it but they have finally crossed the line. It was a length delivery on off, Vettori looks to pull it across the line, closes the bat face early, gets a thick leading edge and the ball flies to the third man fence

24.3   Iain Wardlaw to Milne, no run, fuller around off, Milne gets forward and taps it to mid-off
24.2   Iain Wardlaw to Vettori, 1 run, fullish on the pads, Vettori leans forward and clips it to deep square leg
24.1   Iain Wardlaw to Vettori, 2 runs, shortish and outside off, Vettori drags the pull to deep mid-wicket, where the fielder runs along the rope to his right and cuts off the ball
23.6   Davey to Milne, no run, length delivery on middle and off, Milne blocks it off the front foot
23.5   Davey to Vettori, 1 run, back of a length on leg, Vettori works it off the pads to deep square leg
Adam Milne, right handed bat, comes to the crease

23.4   Davey to Ronchi, out Caught by Gardiner!! This is almost comical by New Zealand! It was a shortish ball from Davey, Ronchi gets back and pulls, finds the man at deep mid-wicket to perfection. He shakes his head as he walks away. Ronchi c Gardiner b Davey 12(10) [4s-2]
Davey to Ronchi, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
23.3   Davey to Ronchi, FOUR, fuller on middle and leg, Ronchi leans forward and flicks it to the deep mid-wicket fence, just beats the fielder and goes through
Daniel Vettori, left handed bat, comes to the crease

23.2   Davey to Corey Anderson, out Caught by Iain Wardlaw!! Another one goes! New Zealand are just 10 runs away from a win and they are falling down rapidly. Anderson picks this one from his pads and flicks it in the air, ends up top-edging it to fine leg. Wardlaw does well to judge the catch and snaffle it in front of the rope. Corey Anderson c Iain Wardlaw b Davey 11(16) [4s-1]
Davey to Corey Anderson, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

23.1   Davey to Corey Anderson, FOUR, fuller on middle, Davey was searching for the yorker there, Anderson leans forward nicely and flicks it between mid-wicket and mid-on to take New Zealand closer to victory

22.6   Iain Wardlaw to Ronchi, FOUR, this time Ronchi has managed to pierce the gap well. Shortish and offering good width, the batsman goes on the back foot and slaps it to the deep backward point fence
22.5   Iain Wardlaw to Ronchi, 2 runs, shortish and outside off, Ronchi cuts it towards square third man, where the fielder dives near the rope and cuts it off
22.4   Iain Wardlaw to Ronchi, no run, length delivery coming back in, Ronchi bunts it just in front of point
22.3   Iain Wardlaw to Ronchi, no run, fuller on off, Ronchi gets forward and jams it back to the bowler, who mock throws it at Ronchi
22.2   Iain Wardlaw to Ronchi, no run, fullish and coming back into the batsman, Ronchi drives it to mid-on
A couple of slips in place
22.1   Iain Wardlaw to Corey Anderson, 1 run, length delivery just outside off, Anderson drives it to mid-off for a brisk single

21.6   Davey to Ronchi, 2 runs, length delivery on middle, Ronchi looks to pull it and mistimes the shot towards long-on but it falls in no-man's land, the man from mid-on backtracks and stops it before the rope
21.5   Davey to Ronchi, no run, back of a length and coming back in a touch, Ronchi works it into the leg-side
21.4   Davey to Ronchi, no run, defends it off the inside half of the bat towards mid-on

21.3   Davey to Corey Anderson, 1 run, dropped by Wardlaw at fine leg! Anderson swivels on the back foot and pulls this short of length delivery hard and flat towards fine leg, where Wardlaw gets his hands to the ball but spills it. That was as easy as it could get, really poor by Wardlaw to drop it
21.2   Davey to Corey Anderson, no run, length delivery around off, Anderson defends it towards the off-side
21.1   Davey to Corey Anderson, 2 runs, fullish on middle, Anderson leans in front and works it to mid-wicket for a couple
Luke Ronchi, right handed bat, comes to the crease

20.6   Iain Wardlaw to Elliott, out Caught by Matthew Cross!! What are New Zealand doing? They have lost half their side in chase of this paltry total. Wardlaw gets his third! It was a back of a length delivery from him, Elliott presses forward and hangs his bat away from his body, nicks it off to the keeper. Elliott c Matthew Cross b Iain Wardlaw 29(31) [4s-5]
Iain Wardlaw to Elliott, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Iain Wardlaw [6.0-0-33-2] is back into the attack

He steps out of the crease to his length delivery and looks to hammer it, gets a thick inside edge and the ball goes through to the keeper, who moves to his left to snaffle it. It was dying down on him but Cross does well to hang onto the take. Williamson was unsure whether that had carried but the umpire sends him off. Williamson c Matthew Cross b Davey 38(45) [4s-6]

Josh Davey [1.0-0-7-0] is back into the attack

Cross was sure that came off the glove and the Scotland players go for a review but the replays were quite clear on that. Good call by umpire Nigel Llong

Loud appeal for a catch taken by the slip fielder. But the umpire is unmoved. Scotland review it after a bit of consulation. Replays show that the ball came off Elliott's forearm. Should be NOT OUT. Yes, the onfield decision stays.
12.1   Haq to Williamson, 1 run, lunges on the front foot and works it to deep mid-wicket

Jamie has something to say about Taylor's wicket: "Taylor's wicket hasn't really dimmed the crowd's enthusiasm. Whooping from a section down behind deep point. The DJ's selection of tracks also keeps people swaying."

Wardlaw will continue after the break. A slip in place
Welcome back. New Zealand are only 80 runs away from securing a comfortable win. Williamson is looking in fine touch and would want to chase this down as quickly as possible.

New Zealand started off brightly, but Guptill got out early after hitting a few fours. Williamson then joined McCullum at the crease, who played aggressively for a little while, but perished while trying to run it down to third man. Currently, Williamson and Taylor are at the crease and Williamson looks in superb nick. New Zealand need 80 runs from 41 overs to win this game. It should be easy, but they need to be wary of the Scottish bowlers. Take a break and join us in a short while to follow the final part of the run-chase.

Our man Jamie describes Guptill's dismissal for us from the ground: "Martin Guptill wafted at the air after getting out. Not a dismissal he'll look back on fondly, obviously. Ian Wardlaw didn't celebrate much. Matt Machan, down at third man, shouting support"

The Black Caps openers are making their way out to the middle. Scotland players are in a huddle. Wardlaw will open the bowling for the Scots and Guptill will be on strike first up. There are 2 slips in place.
Scotland made a dubious record today - 5 batsmen got out on a duck, out of which 4 were golden ducks. This is the most number of ducks for Scotland in an ODI innings.

The New Zealand new ball bowlers - Southee and Boult are becoming an exciting combination. They might be the best exponents of the new cherry going around the world. Milne went past the edge on a number of times, but was unlucky not to have picked up a wicket. Anderson provided the crucial wickets and Vettori ran through the tail. Now upto the hosts' batsmen to chase this down.

Machan and Berrington saw off the threatening spell with some solid batting. The pair did all the hard work and then started to play freely. They added 97 runs for the 5th wicket and got to their respective fifties. However, they fell in quick succession and left Scotland in deeper trouble. The lower-order was no match for Vettori, who outfoxed them with his variations. New Zealand will now come out to bat in 10 minutes time and will bat till the scheduled lunch time, that means they will bat for around 40 minutes.

McCullum at the toss said, that the ball would do a bit for the first 30-45 minutes and it certainly did. But it needed the bowlers to land it in the right areas, Boult and Southee did just that. The latter started with a maiden and the former backed it up with two wickets in the over. Southee then picked up two more to reduce Scotland to 12/4.

New Zealand have decided to review an LBW decision. Wardlaw is the man in question. Was it pad first? Let's see. Vettori's front foot is fine. There were two noises, but it looks to have hit the pad first. The umpire is taking his time, checking all the angles. It definitely hits the pad first. The height looks good as well. Marais Erasmus is the TV umpire. I can't understand why the third umpire is taking so much time. Hawk-Eye shows that the ball is hitting top of middle and Scotland are all out for 142

Our man, Jamie Alter, is at the ground and he has this to say: 'Here come the two teams, to generous applause. Dunedin being Edinburgh's sister town here in New Zealand, the Scottish touch is evident. Makes for an enjoyable setting."
The players are out in the middle.. Can Boult and Southee exploit the early morning moisture and pave the way for another win for the hosts?

Pitch Report: 'It's a nice looking surface. There is some nice grass cover, that's the main thing about it. That should give some pace to the track. The seamers will get some assistance for sure, a little bit of movement early on. If you get through the first 30-45 minutes, it's going to be easy to bat on. No surprises that New Zealand are going to bowl first, they wanted to bowl first in the SL match that was played here (NZ were reduced to 92/5 before being lifted to 360 by Grant Elliott and Luke Ronchi). Look out for Southee and Boult to make some inroads early. For Scotland, get through the first 8-10 overs and they might prosper with some runs, the outfield is in great condition, the shorter boundaries should help the batsmen as well,' reckons Simon Doull
Teams:
New Zealand (Playing XI): Brendon McCullum(c), Martin Guptill, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi(w), Daniel Vettori, Tim Southee, Adam Milne, Trent Boult
Scotland (Playing XI): Kyle Coetzer, Calum MacLeod, Hamish Gardiner, Matt Machan, Preston Mommsen(c), Richie Berrington, Matthew Cross(w), Josh Davey, Rob Taylor, Majid Haq, Iain Wardlaw
New Zealand have won the toss and have opted to field

Preston Mommsen: 'We are also looking forward to the game, very excited to be back at the World Cup. We were looking to bat first anyway, need to get runs on the board and then hopefully put them under pressure. Looks like a good wicket. We want to show off our skills and hopefully today provides us that opportunity. We are very happy with our preparations and feeling very confident. We had some good results against Ireland and took West Indies pretty close as well.'

Brendon McCullum: 'We will bowl first, there will be a bit in it for the first 45 minutes, will look to exploit the early moisture on the wicket. We had a training session yesterday. Great to be at Dunedin. Looking forward to the match, we will treat it as any other World Cup match. Great opportunity to execute our skills, no changes to our team.'

The Scots were here last October as part of the ICC warm-up programme where the Associates were given an opportunity to get useful match practice in these conditions. Up against a New Zealand XI that included as many as 8 players currently featuring in the World Cup, they came close to upstaging the fancied Kiwis. Chasing 263, they fell short by the smallest margin of one run. Can they pull off a stunning heist today?

On the other hand, Preston Mommsen, Scotland's captain, is quietly confident of putting up a good show against the co-hosts, who are also one of the top favourites to win the prestigious tournament. "I think we have quite a dynamic side. Obviously inexperienced in terms of playing on the world stage, but at the same time, I think we can use that to our advantage. Very raw team, so there will be a huge amount of energy there, a huge amount of passion, and the boys will be playing very hard," he said.

New Zealand captain, Brendon McCullum, spoke ahead of the match and said he was expecting a good fight from the inexperienced Scotland team. He also ruled out any complacency by the hosts. "We've got to make sure we're on our game and treat it as if we're playing one of the bigger teams, as well, because in this World Cup I think we've seen at the moment with West Indies under a little bit of pressure, as well, that the Associate teams certainly have players capable of standing up and making things pretty uncomfortable for you," he said.

Weather Report: It's a bright and sunny day at Dunedin with the temperature expected to hover around the 20 degree mark. There's no threat of rain and the wind is expected to blow from the Northeast direction.

History Book: The two teams have met each other twice and it isn't a massive surprise that New Zealand recorded thumping wins in both encounters. They haven't played each other since 2008 though and that means the current set of Scottish players would have very little in terms of scars from the last hiding.

09:45 Local Time, 20:45 GMT, 02:15 IST: The World Cup carnival has moved across to the southern most city of New Zealand. We are at the University Oval in Dunedin where the hosts entertain Scotland in their second match of the World Cup. The hosts have already started on a winning note, demolishing Sri Lanka in the inaugural match of the tournament. For Preston Mommsen and his merry band of Scottish cricketers, it's an opportunity to prove themselves in front of the global audience.

Preview

Moments before Preston Mommsen walked in for his final interaction with the media before Scotland's World Cup opener against New Zealand at University Oval on Tuesday, the sound of Scottish bagpipes could be heard coming from one of the adjacent playing fields on the campus of the University of Otago. It must have been part of the university band's practice routines for orientation week - the campus is starting to get active with new arrivals and their parents, as well as returning students - but the sounds of bagpipes was another reminder of where Mommsen's Scotland team are based: Dunedin, known as the Edinburgh of the South, and indeed planned in light of its Scottish predecessor.

Game six of the World Cup pits Scotland against New Zealand, who hammered Sri Lanka by 98 runs in the tournament opener in Christchurch, but Mommsen will be hoping that a bit of Dunedin's Scottish heritage rubs off and motivates his Associates-level team against the in-form home team.

Mommsen was born in South Africa, but today proudly leads Scotland into their third World Cup - after winless runs in 1999 and 2007 - and was confident of the way the team has entered the tournament. "I think we have quite a dynamic side," he said. "Obviously inexperienced in terms of playing on the world stage, but at the same time, I think we can use that to our advantage. Very raw team, so there will be a huge amount of energy there, a huge amount of passion, and the boys will be playing very hard."

Scotland's two warm-ups in Australia resulted in a 179-run win over Ireland and a three-run defeat to West Indies when they were chasing 313, but they will also take a bit of confidence from a practice game against a New Zealand XI featuring Martin Guptill, Brendon McCullum, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi, Daniel Vettori, Mitchell McClenaghan and Kyle Mills in Lincoln, last October.

"We watched a video this morning of that game, and we took a huge amount from that game. We took them very close, and really we should have won that game," said Mommsen. "A lot of the guys playing tomorrow played in that game, so we've got that to call upon, and hopefully we can produce a similar performance tomorrow and take the game deep. The buildup has been near perfect for the boys. We're very realistic about the opposition that we're up against. Obviously, New Zealand are a quality team, and the form they are currently in, they're going to be a difficult team to break down. But at the same time, we've prepared as we have for every other game in the leadup to this game tomorrow, and hopefully we can put in a good performance."

Brendon McCullum was part of that game a few months ago, and he too spoke of the team sitting down to watch the video of it. "Yeah, we did some scouting this morning on the bowlers. I've had plenty of footage the last little while that we can get our hands on and I've obviously tried to cover that, as well," he said. :That's one of our big things as a team, that we make sure we go in well planned and well prepared, but they gave us a good run for our money at Lincoln a few months ago. Yeah, we've got to make sure we're on our game and treat it as if we're playing one of the bigger teams, as well, because in this World Cup, I think we've seen at the moment with West Indies under a little bit of pressure, as well, that the Associate teams certainly have players capable of standing up and making things pretty uncomfortable for you."

New Zealand have been a dominant team over the last 15-odd months, winning big series home and away, and this World Cup is being talked of in certain circles as their best shot at victory. Fully aware of the level of competition Scotland are up against, Mommsen sounded confident when assessing his team.

"I don't think we're daunted by the way they play. Obviously, the focus has very much been on the way we want to play our game tomorrow," he said. "At the same time, we know they're dangerous. It's a dangerous lineup from 1 to 11. At the same time, they're still human beings, they still can nick the ball and get caught at slip. We have to put the balls in the right areas and make sure we're able to contain them. Obviously, we can draw on that experience of coming up against West Indies, a very dangerous batting lineup with Chris Gayle, Darren Sammy, Andre Russell towards the deaths, so that was good experience and very recent for us, and we'll call upon that. We're going into this game tomorrow with a huge amount of confidence."

The wicket at University Oval looks a good batting surface, but as both captains said, the angles on a small ground are what could be the deciding factor. While Mommsen felt Scotland would have to play 'smart cricket' on this ground, McCullum harked back to two ODIs played here in January with Sri Lanka, in which New Zealand made 360 and 315.

"Obviously, Australia is a different kettle of fish in terms of their size grounds and things like that, but I think our grounds are really, really good," he said. "They've got some quirks about them, and this one, as well, with the boundaries straight, obviously a little bit shorter, but there's certainly some getout areas, as well, for bowlers with the big boundaries, but I think the pitch looks really good. I'd expect a lot of runs, especially if we get, I guess, some clear skies over here, which I believe is forecast, then I'd expect a lot of runs, I guess, similar to the games we had against Sri Lanka down here."

Hamish Gardiner, who batted at No 3 in the warm-ups and made 12 and 7, could be swapped with Freddie Coleman who batted at one-drop in the UAE last month. The bowling is unlikely to change much from those fixtures, with Scotland heavily dependent on the offspin of 31-year-old Majid Haq - only the second player from the country to cross 200 caps - and medium-pacer Alasdair Evans, with seven wickets in the warm-ups. They will, as Mommsen pointed out, expect a lot from their new-ball pair of Ian Wardlaw and Josh Davey, who earlier this year took ten wickets between them to rout Afghanistan for just 63.

There have been suggestions that New Zealand could make changes for this match, but McCullum dodged that question by saying: "We're going to play our cards pretty close to our chest with the team, but all the guys are fit and available, and it's a good space for us to be in. We've got a fully fit and strong team to pick from, so we'll just work out the strategy that we want to go in with tomorrow."
